item.title: Trump’s Foreign Policy: Resurrecting Empire
item.description: President Trump’s approach is a revival of the mission of empire — acquiring the territories and resources of sovereign peoples.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio, right, has been leading the Trump administration’s foreign policy.

item.title: Pentagon Fires Another Laser at Drone, Prompting New Air Closure
item.description: After the downing of a Customs and Border Protection drone, the F.A.A. closed the airspace above Fort Hancock, Texas.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian, Kate Kelly, Eric Schmitt and Chris Cameron
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)
item.media:description: A police officer walked with a police dog at El Paso International Airport, after the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration lifted its temporary closure of the airspace over El Paso earlier this month.

item.title: Fact-check: In Trump’s Case for an Attack on Iran, False or Unproven Claims
item.description: Key elements of the Trump administration’s arguments this week for another military campaign against Iran do not hold up.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Edward Wong, David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: People walked past a missile system and banners of Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, in Tehran last year.

item.title: Vance Continues to Criticize Democrats’ Attitude During State of the Union
item.description: Speaking in Wisconsin to support Republicans ahead of the midterm elections, Vice President JD Vance reminded his audience that Democrats had not stood up at the president’s behest on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: Vice President JD Vance in Plover, Wisc., on Thursday.

item.title: Minnesota Offers Plan to Fight Fraud as Trump Moves to Freeze Funds
item.description: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota laid out legislative measures to prevent fraud after a scandal that has upended the political landscape in the state.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota at a news conference at the State Capitol in St. Paul earlier this month.

item.title: Trump Ally Expands Inquiry of Former Officials Who Investigated the President
item.description: The office of a prosecutor based in Miami has issued new subpoenas in a wide-ranging inquiry aimed at President Trump’s perceived foes.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some of President Trump’s allies have hoped that Jason A. Reding Quiñones, the U.S. attorney for the District of Southern Florida, would develop a “grand conspiracy” inquiry.

item.title: Supreme Court Lawyer Who Moonlighted in High-Stakes Poker Is Convicted of Tax Fraud
item.description: The lawyer Thomas C. Goldstein, who co-founded the SCOTUSblog website, hid millions in gambling income from the government, federal prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: Thomas Goldstein represented Epic Games, makers of the popular Fortnite video game, in an antitrust case brought against Apple in the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, in 2022.

item.title: Dog Abandoned at Las Vegas Airport Adopted by Responding Police Officer
item.description: The previous owner was arrested and charged with animal abandonment and resisting arrest, police said.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:description: A dog abandoned by its owner at the Las Vegas airport didn’t need long to find a new home.

item.title: Justice Department Sues 5 States, Most Republican-Led, for Voter Data
item.description: The Trump administration sued Utah, Oklahoma and West Virginia, as well as Kentucky and New Jersey, to obtain unredacted voter registration databases in pursuit of baseless claims of voter fraud.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:description: Election processing in Salt Lake City in 2024. Utah was one of five states sued by the Trump administration on Thursday for voter data.

item.title: After F.B.I. Raid, Los Angeles School Board Discusses Superintendent’s Future
item.description: Board members held an emergency meeting a day after agents raided the home and office of Alberto Carvalho, the Los Angeles Unified School District superintendent. They did not reach a resolution and agreed to reconvene Friday.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein and Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Los Angeles Unified school board members met Thursday afternoon in an emergency closed session a day after the F.B.I. raid of Alberto Carvalho’s home.

item.title: Federal Judge Accuses Trump Administration of Repeatedly Disobeying Orders
item.description: The federal judge identified 210 orders issued in 143 cases in Minnesota in which he said Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials had not complied with court orders.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith, Ernesto Londoño and Mattathias Schwartz
item.media:credit: U.S. District Court of Minnesota, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Judge Patrick Schiltz was nominated to the bench by President George W. Bush.

item.title: Testimony Offers New Details on Justice Dept. Role in Abrego Garcia Prosecution
item.description: A top prosecutor, Robert E. McGuire, painted an extraordinary picture of senior Justice Department leaders peering over his shoulder and hurrying him along.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:description: Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia and his wife, Jennifer Vasquez Sura, arriving at federal court in Nashville on Thursday.

item.title: Jo Ann Bland, Child Activist in Civil Rights Struggle, Dies at 72
item.description: At 11, she was one of the youngest at the 1965 “Bloody Sunday” voting rights march in Selma, Ala., and was injured while crossing the Edmund Pettus Bridge.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:credit: Jessica Rinaldi/The Boston Globe, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Ms. Bland, right, was embraced by a crowd crossing the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma in 2015 to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the civil rights march.

item.title: N.Y. Doctor’s Bid to Avoid Extradition to Japan Fails in Court
item.description: Dr. Masahide Kanayama could be sent to Japan next week to face charges that he vandalized ancient religious sites, federal prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Kanayama in his office in Manhattan last year.

item.title: Regime Change in Cuba Appeals to Trump but Carries Risks
item.description: The Trump administration is signaling a different approach, after demanding an end to Cuba’s communist leadership.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: “Cuba does not kneel,” the country’s president, Miguel Díaz-Canel, center, told a state-run newspaper this month.

item.title: Jesse Jackson Memorials Begin in Chicago
item.description: Mourners lined up outside Rainbow PUSH, the organization Mr. Jackson founded decades ago. He died last week at 84.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman and Jamie Kelter Davis
item.media:description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, a prominent civil rights leader and the founder of the Rainbow PUSH Coalition, died on Feb. 17.

item.title: Trump’s Go-To Tactic in the State of the Union
item.description: Our reporter Zolan Kanno-Youngs examines the context of a moment in the State of the Union speech when President Trump turned to a favorite tactic on immigration.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Gilad Thaler, Thomas Vollkommer, Laura Salaberry and Ray Whitehouse

item.title: Chicago Man Faces U.S. Charges in Woman’s Killing During Bali Trip
item.description: The man is accused of conspiring with his then girlfriend to kill her mother, whose body was stuffed in a suitcase. He spent 11 years in prison in Bali, Indonesia, on related charges.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:description: Tommy Schaefer at Gusti Ngurah Rai International Airport in Bali this week, before being deported to the United States, where he made his first appearance in a Chicago federal court.

item.title: The Minnesota Welfare Fraud Scandal Explained
item.description: An inquiry into scams involving money slated for social services has deepened over the years. It also is at the center of several recent domestic decisions by the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents executed a search warrant in December as part of a fraud investigation in Bloomington, Minn.

item.title: Trump Declared Victory in Minneapolis. But What Did He Accomplish?
item.description: The Trump administration came under fire for an operation that turned lethal and politically toxic. But the show of force may also have had a bigger purpose: to serve as a warning.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: Federal agents confronting protesters in Minneapolis last month. Sheriffs and public officials across the state say little, if anything, has changed about their immigration enforcement policies since the federal operation.

item.title: Government Still Building Case for U.S.S. Cole Trial 25 Years After Attack
item.description: Prosecutors are scrambling to shore up the case from adverse judicial rulings. Defense lawyers say they are not ready for trial.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:description: The attack on the U.S.S. Cole killed 17 American sailors off the coast of Yemen in 2000.

item.title: Dan Duckhorn, Who Transformed Napa Valley Merlot, Is Dead At 87
item.description: A founder of Duckhorn Vineyards, a California winemaker, Mr. Duckhorn transformed merlot from a blending grape into a premier American variety.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Dan Duckhorn in an undated photograph. “There was no economic reason for starting out in merlot,” he said in 1995, adding that it was simply “what I liked.”

item.title: Denver Mayor Bars ICE From City Property and Orders Protection for Protesters
item.description: Mayor Mike Johnston’s order is a defiant shift from his measured stance and risks drawing attention to Greater Denver after President Trump during the campaign promised a “bloody story” there.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Mike Johnston of Denver at the U.S. Capitol testifying at a congressional hearing last year.

item.title: In Texas, Crenshaw faces primary challenger, a test for MAGA
item.description: Representative Dan Crenshaw, who has at times clashed with President Trump and his allies, is facing a conservative challenger in Tuesday’s primary.
item.dc:creator: Tim Balk and J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Bob Daemmrich/Alamy, Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: State Representative Steve Toth is locked in a Republican primary battle with Representative Dan Crenshaw.

item.title: Trump Administration Asks Supreme Court to End Protections for Syrian Migrants
item.description: The president has sought to end the program, known as Temporary Protected Status, for various migrants as part of his mass deportation efforts.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed mosque in Darayya, near Damascus, last year. The U.S. government initially put protections in place for migrants from Syria in 2012, citing the “extraordinary and temporary conditions” in the country resulting from “a brutal crackdown” by former President Bashar al-Assad.

item.title: Hillary Clinton Denies Knowing Epstein or His Crimes in a Tense Deposition
item.description: After resisting testifying for months, the former secretary of state entered the session defiant, and grew irate after a Republican leaked a photo from inside the room.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

item.title: Judge Declines to Halt Construction on Trump’s East Wing Ballroom Project
item.description: A federal judge ruled that a lawsuit challenging the project needed to be revised before he could consider the larger questions it presented.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.category: Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington
item.media:description: The site of the demolished East Wing of the White House in December.

item.title: Justice Gorsuch’s Tariffs Warning
item.description: Granting a president new power is easy, he said. But taking it back is almost impossible.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: Family of U.N. Expert Critical of Israel Sues Trump Over Sanctions
item.description: The family of Francesca Albanese, a critic of Israel’s war in Gaza, asked a court to void the Trump administration’s sanctions against her.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: The family of Francesca Albanese sued the Trump administration over its imposition of sanctions against her.

item.title: Fine Oak Farms Fire in Ohio Kills 6,000 Hogs
item.description: Police officials said the cause of the conflagration near Columbus is under investigation. It took four hours to extinguish and the carcasses are buried beneath wreckage.
item.dc:creator: Billy Witz
item.media:description: Smoke rising from a fire at an Ohio hog farm complex in Madison County, Ohio, on Wednesday.

item.title: Why Are So Many Democrats Running for California Governor?
item.description: With California’s political machine on the wane, nobody has emerged as a clear front-runner. Democrats worry that nine of their candidates could split the vote and hand Republicans a win.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Democrats have grown concerned that too many candidates for governor may split the primary vote and let two Republicans advance to the general election.

item.title: How Texas School Vouchers Could Make Child Care More Affordable
item.description: Republicans have embraced vouchers, while Democrats have criticized them. But as thousands of preschool parents vie for the funds, the state program may help a progressive goal.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:description: Pre-K students at a school in San Antonio.

item.title: Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders’s Plan to Build a Prison in Arkansas Divides GOP
item.description: Gov. Sarah Huckabee Sanders wants to build a huge, pricey prison to hold the inmates incarcerated under her tough-on-crime agenda, and she hopes to oust fellow Republicans on Tuesday to do it.
item.dc:creator: David W. Chen and Terra Fondriest
item.media:description: A nondescript gate marks the entrance to land purchased for a 3,000-bed prison in Arkansas that has divided Republicans ahead of Tuesday’s primaries.

item.title: How A.I.-Generated Videos Are Distorting Your Child’s YouTube Feed
item.description: Experts caution that low-quality, A.I.-generated videos on YouTube geared toward children often feature conflicting information, lack plot structure and can be cognitively overwhelming — all of which could affect young children’s development.
item.dc:creator: Arijeta Lajka
